review.title: An Integer Programming Model for Binary Knapsack Problem with Value-Related Dependencies among Elements
review.abstract: Binary Knapsack Problem (BKP) is to select a subset of an element (item) set with the highest value while keeping the total weight within the capacity of the knapsack. This paper presents an integer programming model for a variation of BKP where the value of each element may depend on selecting or ignoring other elements. Strengths of such Value-Related Dependencies are assumed to be imprecise and hard to specify. To capture this imprecision, we have proposed modeling value-related dependencies using fuzzy graphs and their algebraic structure.

metadata.title: An Integer Programming Model for Binary Knapsack Problem with Value-Related Dependencies among Elements

sections.text: ar Xiv: 170 2.06 662v 1 [cs.A I] 2 2Fe b20 17Binary crimp bag problem (BKP) consists in selecting a subset of an element (item) with the highest value, keeping the total weight within the capacity of the knapsack. Paper represents a complex programming model for a variant of BKP, in which the value of an element can depend on whether other elements are selected or ignored. Strengths of such value-related dependencies are assumed to be inaccurate and difficult to specify. To capture this imprecision, we have proposed to model value-related dependencies using blurred graphs and their algebraic structure. KEYWORDSBinary crimp problem, Integrated programming, dependence, value

sections.heading: 1 MODELING DEPENDENCIES
sections.text: Fuzzy graphs have been shown to correctly grasp the inaccuracy of real world problems [4, 6]. Therefore, we have used the algebraic structure of fuzzy graphs to grasp the inaccuracy associated with the strengths of value-related dependencies. We have specifically used the classic dependence on fuzzy graphs (VDG) to consider not only the strengths but also the qualities (positive or negative) of value-related dependencies (De nition 1).De nition 1. Value dependence graph (VDG).A VDG is a signet-direct fuzzy graph [11] G = (E, fractional value), in which a non-empty placement of the elements E: {e1, en} the graphs constitute the nodes. Also, the qualitative function: E · E → {+, −, ±} and the member function: E →.

sections.heading: 3 SUMMARY
sections.text: In this thesis, we presented an integer programming model for solving a variation of the binary knapsack problem, in which the value of each element can be influenced by selecting or ignoring other elements. The strengths of these elements in Uenenses (value-related dependencies) are assumed to be inaccurate and difficult to express. The algebraic structure of fuzzy graphs was used to grasp the imprecision associated with the strengths of value-related dependencies.
